Rank 3 subgroups of finite symplectic and unitary groups ')
By D,  G,  Higman and /. E,  McLaughlin at Ann Arbor ( Mich. )
1.  Introduction
Denote by Autô ( P ) the group of all those collineations of the projective space P,  of dimension d over the field which commute with a given polarity ô of symplectic ( i.  e. , null ) or unitary type.  The subgroup T { P ) = T ^{ P ) generated by all the elations in Autô ( P ), called the projective special symplectic group or the projective special unitary group according as à is of symplectic or unitary type,  is a simple group in all but six cases ( see for example [ 1,  2 ]). In the unitary case q must be a square,  q = ql \ it will prove convenient to put q ' m the symplectic case. 
The rank of a transitive permutation group is defined to be the number of orbits for the stabilizer of a point [ 4 ]. Thus the rank is always at least 2,  and rank 2 means double transitivity.  The group Aut ^( P ) can be regarded as a group of permutations of the set of absolute points of P ( a point P is called absolute if it lies on = й ( Р )), and as such is transitive since T { P ) is transitive.  For d = 1 or 2,  T { P ) is even doubly tran sitive ( of course for d = 2,  as for all even d,  only the unitary case is possible ). It is shown in § 8 that for d = 2,  any subgroup of Aut ^( P ) which is doubly transitive on the absolute points of P must contain T { P ), For й ^ 3 it is clear that Autô ( P ) must have rank at least 3,  since the stabilizer of a point P also stabilizes P ^. The fact is that Autö ( P ) has exactly rank 3 for d ^ 3,  as does T ( P ), The problem arises of determining the rank 3 subgroups of Autô ( P ), d ^ 3. 
Assuming that q ^ > 4,  we show in § 9 that any normal subgroup Ф 1 of a rank 3 subgroup G of Auta ( P ) again has rank 3.  ( We don ’ t know if the restriction on q ^ can be removed entirely,  but if we assume that G consists of projectivities,  we need only assume that ÿo > 3. ) It follows with this restriction on go that,  firstly,  minimal rank 3 subgroups of Autô ( P ) are simple,  and secondly,  if G is a rank 3 subgroup,  so is G T { P ). The main question therefore,  is whether T ( P ) is a minimal rank 3 subgroup.  In § 10 is is shown that for 3 ^ d ^ 7,  T { P ) is minimal with the following possible exceptions in the symplectic case :
d = 3,  go = 2,  and d = 5 or 7,  go even. 
The only case which we know to be actually exceptional is the symplectic case
with d = 3,  go = 2,  where the alternating group of degree 6 acts as a rank 3 subgroup
of T ( P ) while T { P ) is isomorphic to the symmetric group of degree 6.  The symplectic
case with d = 5,  go = 2 can,  in fact be ruled out,  but we do not give the rather lengthy details here.  These results can be considered as symplectic and unitary analogues of
